guide.conclusion: This project first appeared in MAKE Volume 22, page 78.

flags.title: From MAKE Magazine
flags.text: This project first appeared on the pages of MAKE magazine.

guide.introduction:
Making play-dough creatures is fun, but making them with light-up eyes and moving parts is even more enjoyable. We thought it would be better still if we could make the circuitry out of the dough itself!

Most play dough is already conductive, but we needed a way to insulate the conductive dough. We came up with a sugar-based dough that works well as an insulator. It’s pliable and resistant to blending with the conductive dough.

Rainy day and fidgety kids? Whip up both types of dough, gather some LEDs and batteries, and create your own menagerie of squishy circuit creations. Add a motor or two for sculptures with moving parts. Feeling adventurous? Play with the salt content of the recipes to vary their conductivity.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Making play-dough creatures is fun, but making them with light-up eyes and moving parts is even more enjoyable. We thought it would be better still if we could make the circuitry out of the dough itself!

Most play dough is already conductive, but we needed a way to insulate the conductive dough. We came up with a sugar-based dough that works well as an insulator. It’s pliable and resistant to blending with the conductive dough.

Rainy day and fidgety kids? Whip up both types of dough, gather some LEDs and batteries, and create your own menagerie of squishy circuit creations. Add a motor or two for sculptures with moving parts. Feeling adventurous? Play with the salt content of the recipes to vary their conductivity.

Relevant parts
  • Batteries
  • Water
  • LED
  • Flour
  • Salt
  • Cream of tartar
  • Food coloring
  • Sugar
  • Vegetable oil
  • Distilled water
  • (optional) motors or buzzers
Tools
  • Battery holder
  • crimping tool (optional)
  • soldering iron (optional)

parts.notes: or deionized water; check lab supply stores

lines.text: Ingredients for conductive dough:
lines.text_raw: Ingredients for conductive dough:

lines.text: 1c water
lines.text_raw: 1c water

lines.text: 1½c flour
lines.text_raw: 1½c flour

lines.text: ¼c salt
lines.text_raw: ¼c salt

lines.text: 3Tbsp cream of tartar (or 9 Tbsp of lemon juice)
lines.text_raw: 3Tbsp cream of tartar (or 9 Tbsp of lemon juice)

lines.text: 1Tbsp vegetable oil
lines.text_raw: 1Tbsp vegetable oil

lines.text: Food coloring (optional)
lines.text_raw: Food coloring (optional)

lines.text: Make the conductive dough.
lines.text_raw: Make the conductive dough.

lines.text: Reserve ½c flour, and mix the remaining ingredients in a medium-sized pot. Cook over medium heat, stirring continuously. The mixture will begin to boil and get chunky. Keep stirring until a ball forms in the center of the pot. Once a ball forms, turn off the heat and remove the dough to a lightly floured surface.
lines.text_raw: Reserve ½c flour, and mix the remaining ingredients in a medium-sized pot. Cook over medium heat, stirring continuously. The mixture will begin to boil and get chunky. Keep stirring until a ball forms in the center of the pot. Once a ball forms, turn off the heat and remove the dough to a lightly floured surface.

lines.text: CAUTION: The dough will be very hot! Flatten it and let it cool for a couple of minutes before handling.
lines.text_raw: CAUTION: The dough will be very hot! Flatten it and let it cool for a couple of minutes before handling.

lines.text: Slowly knead the remaining flour into the ball until you’ve reached the desired consistency.
lines.text_raw: Slowly knead the remaining flour into the ball until you’ve reached the desired consistency.

lines.text: Store dough in an airtight container or plastic bag. In the bag, water from the dough will create condensation. This is normal. Just knead the dough after removing it from the bag, and it will be as good as new. Stored properly, it should keep for several weeks. If it dries out, just add a little more deionized water and knead it with some flour.
lines.text_raw: Store dough in an airtight container or plastic bag. In the bag, water from the dough will create condensation. This is normal. Just knead the dough after removing it from the bag, and it will be as good as new. Stored properly, it should keep for several weeks. If it dries out, just add a little more deionized water and knead it with some flour.

lines.text: Ingredients for the insulating dough:
lines.text_raw: Ingredients for the insulating dough:

lines.text: 1½c flour
lines.text_raw: 1½c flour

lines.text: ½c sugar
lines.text_raw: ½c sugar

lines.text: 3Tbsp vegetable oil
lines.text_raw: 3Tbsp vegetable oil

lines.text: ½c distilled or deionized water
lines.text_raw: ½c distilled or deionized water

lines.text: Mix the dry ingredients and oil in a pot or large bowl. Mix in 1Tbsp of deionized water and knead; repeat until the mixture becomes moist and dough-like.
lines.text_raw: Mix the dry ingredients and oil in a pot or large bowl. Mix in 1Tbsp of deionized water and knead; repeat until the mixture becomes moist and dough-like.

lines.text: Remove the mixture from the pot or bowl, and slowly knead flour into it until it attains a firm consistency. You should use almost the entire ½c of flour.
lines.text_raw: Remove the mixture from the pot or bowl, and slowly knead flour into it until it attains a firm consistency. You should use almost the entire ½c of flour.

lines.text: NOTE: You probably won’t need more than ¼c of deionized water, but have ½c ready just in case.
lines.text_raw: NOTE: You probably won’t need more than ¼c of deionized water, but have ½c ready just in case.

lines.text: Insert the 2 leads from the battery pack into 2 pieces of conductive dough, separated by a lump of insulating dough (we recommend using food coloring to differentiate the doughs).
lines.text_raw: Insert the 2 leads from the battery pack into 2 pieces of conductive dough, separated by a lump of insulating dough (we recommend using food coloring to differentiate the doughs).

lines.text: Insert an LED so its anode (long lead) is in the positive battery lump, and its cathode (short lead) is in the negative battery lump. It will light up!
lines.text_raw: Insert an LED so its anode (long lead) is in the positive battery lump, and its cathode (short lead) is in the negative battery lump. It will light up!

lines.text: Always attach LEDs or other components to the dough. Never attach them directly to the battery pack, as running too much current through components can damage them, possibly causing them to overheat or pop.
lines.text_raw: Always attach LEDs or other components to the dough. Never attach them directly to the battery pack, as running too much current through components can damage them, possibly causing them to overheat or pop.

lines.text: Note that this will work best if you attach leads to your battery pack's wires: http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/apthomas/S...
lines.text_raw: Note that this will work best if you attach leads to your battery pack's wires: http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/apthomas/SquishyCircuits/leads.htm

lines.text: More ideas for circuits that can be built using squishy circuits can be found here: http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/apthomas/S...
lines.text_raw: More ideas for circuits that can be built using squishy circuits can be found here: http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/apthomas/SquishyCircuits/buildingCircuits.htm

guide.summary: Make play-dough creatures with light-up eyes by making the circuitry out of the dough itself!
guide.title: Squishy Circuits
